Award.AwardTitle: Testing geochemical proxy relationships under variable paleo-seawater chemical compositions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The application of proxies to paleoceanographic reconstructions relies on calibrations that may be sensitive to changes in the ocean's chemistry (e.g., elemental abundances, isotopic composition). This project, led by a faculty member at Columbia University's Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory, will test the assumption that the sensitivity of paleo-proxies has remained constant as ocean chemistry has changed over time. Planktonic foraminifera, a common paleo-proxy archive, will be cultured in the laboratory under a range of seawater chemistries representing changing ocean conditions from the Eocene to the Cretaceous (~50 to 100 million years before present). The effects of these changing conditions will be assessed for several proxies, including stable oxygen and carbon isotopes and the B/Ca proxy for seawater carbonate chemistry. Complementary studies will examine the association and photosynthetic activity of symbiotic algae, which also affect chemical proxy composition in foraminifera shells.

This research will advance our capacity to quantify past changes in ocean and climate, and thereby to understand potential for future changes. Funding supports a variety of education, outreach, and service activities. One graduate and one undergraduate student from the U.S. will be involved in the project, and two graduate students from Australia will also contribute. In addition, two high school students from the Young Women's Leadership School in East Harlem, New York City, will participate in the culturing program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project performed laboratory experiments with modern calcifying plankton organisms called foraminifera to ocean conditions in the Paleocene-Eocene (~50-60 million years ago).

 

Planktic foraminifera are microscopic, single-celled plankton that incorporate the chemistry of the seawater they live in into their shells. When they die and the empty shells sinks to the bottom of the ocean, this information is archived in the sediments that build up over time. Paleoceanographers extract this information and it allows them to reconstruct the environmental conditions at the time when the foraminifers lived. The motivation for this type of study is that understanding the natural course of environmental events and quantifying their extent can help us improve predictions for future climate and ecosystem changes in the light of ongoing human-induced carbon dioxide emissions and climate change.

 

56 million years ago, a natural ocean acidification event occurred on Earth that led to the dissolution of most carbonates at the bottom of the ocean, to global warming and to extinction and subsequent evolution in marine ecosystems. Many have suggested that we can learn about the Earth’s response to rapid warming and ocean acidification by studying this ancient event. The boron-to-calcium ratio (B/Ca) in planktic foraminifera shells has been suggested as a way to reconstruct seawater acidity. However, application to the Paleocene/Eocene yielded results that were difficult to interpret with calibration studies performed with modern foraminifera species grown in modern seawater. Applying modern calibrations to such ancient fossils is difficult because the plankton organisms of the Paleocene/Eocene are now extinct, and the chemical composition of seawater was characterized by a different overall chemistry, as well as a potentially massive addition of carbon that drove ocean acidification and global warming.

 

To resolve this issue, we performed experiments under simulated Paleocene/Eocene seawater conditions but with modern, living planktic foraminifera. To do this, we made artificial seawater that mirrored the chemistry of the Paleocene/Eocene Ocean. These experiments resolved that the chemical composition of seawater at the Paleocene/Eocene makes the B/Ca ratio in planktic foraminifera shells more sensitive to acidification and carbon addition compared to the modern ocean. Application to the Paleocene/Eocene now allows us to determine the amount of carbon added to the ocean-atmosphere system at that time.

 

In addition, we measured the photosynthetic activity of symbiotic algae associated with modern foraminifera shells. Photosynthesis is one of the most important physiological processes that can alter the chemical conditions in the immediate area where the foraminifer makes its shell, and quantifying the extent of such physiological processes in the foraminiferal microenvironment is important for trusting the geochemical composition of a foraminifer shell to record surface ocean conditions. We therefore studied the extent of photosynthesis in three different foraminifer species that record different B/Ca ratios. We could not detect a difference in photosynthetic activity or symbiont density between these three species that could explain the different in B/Ca ratios. Consequently, the observed difference in B/Ca ratios must be related to the biomineralization process, which is much less likely to change in response to external environmental changes. Although this result does not yet fully explain the cause for the geochemical offsets, it narrows down the options and allows for more targeted future experiments.

 

Training young scientists and public outreach:

This project allowed the training of three graduate students and one postdoc, who have been guided to design and perform the laboratory experiments, interpret data and bring them to publication. One of the trainees is an African American student who participated in Columbia University’s Bridge-to-the-PhD program, which pairs minority students with potential for graduate school but ineffective mentoring and weak grade averages during their undergraduate career to researchers at Columbia University. Through tailored mentoring, exposure to targeted research and additional courseworks this student is now enrolled in the graduate program at UC Davis.

In addition, results from this study have been incorporated into a scholarly book on reconstructing ocean acidity and atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations from planktic foraminifera, lectures at the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology, several presentations at international conferences and universities, and a public lecture in Hobart, Tasmania.
